2022.title: Release 3.2 improves user experience with bug fixing
2022.text:
Metabolic Atlas 3.2 is out. In this minor release, a number of visual bugs for the Interaction Partners and 3D Map Viewer have been fixed. Moreover, incorrectly formatted metabolite names and chemicals in reaction equations are now revised. Apart from that, the global search functionality is improved by removing the duplicated hits and finally, the overall performance of the server is improved with a setup reconfiguration so that the users will not experience unexpected timeout.
More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2022.title: Release 3.1 improves Interaction Partners and Data Overlay
2022.text:
Metabolic Atlas 3.1 is out. The Interaction Partners has been redone, and it now shares the same underlying solution as the 3D Map Viewer. With this, the library used for rendering networks has also been updated and improved. Moreover, the Data Overlay, which is shared between the Interaction Partners and the Map Viewer, has been extended to support reaction data overlay, in addition to multiple simultaneous data overlays of different types. These data types have also been renamed to better reflect their usage.
Numerous small bugs have been resolved, and the software stack has seen several major updates. Finally, the integrated models have been updated as well.
More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2022.title: Poster at ICSB
2022.text: A poster of of Metabolic Atlas, presenting the work that culminated in the 3.0 release, was presented at the ICSB conference in Berlin, Germany.

2022.title: Poster at ECCB
2022.text: A poster of Metabolic Atlas, presenting the work leading to the 3.0 release, was presented at the ECCB conference in Sitges, Spain.

2022.title: Metabolic Atlas 3.0 presents GotEnzymes
2022.text:
We are delighted to announce the official release of Metabolic Atlas 3.0 ðŸŽ‰ In this major release we provide access to the newly created database GotEnzymes published in Nucleic Acids Research. GotEnzymes contains over 25.7 million predicted enzyme turnover numbers (kcat) for +5.8 million unique sequences and 4147 compounds, across 8099 species. The values are predicted by cutting-edge artificial intelligence tools. In addition, Metabolic Atlas has obtained an Identifiers.org profile and has improved the About pages.
More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2022.title: Metabolic Atlas 2.6 adds a feature to visualise model updates
2022.text: Metabolic Atlas 2.6 is out. In this minor release we have added a new feature for visualizing the history and development of the integrated GEMs, updated the model versions, improved the GEM comparison and the search functionality and fixed a number of bugs. Improvements of the readability and ease of navigation of the web page have been added as well. More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2022.title: Metabolic Atlas 2.5 improves the About pages and fixes bugs
2022.text: Metabolic Atlas 2.5 is out. In this minor release we have focused on maintenance, fixing a number of bugs related to search and broken links. General improvements for the content pages, including the About pages and Documentation, have been added as well. More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2022.title: Metabolic Atlas 2.4 improves search functionality
2022.text: Metabolic Atlas 2.4 is out. In this minor release we have focused on improving the search functionality. The improvement has been achieved for both the GEM Search and the Global Search by a better scoring of searching items and a more logical presentation of found results. Moreover, we have resolved a number of small bugs that affected the user experience. More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2022.title: Metabolic Atlas 2.3 adds info about the project
2022.text: Metabolic Atlas 2.3 is out. In this incremental minor release, we have improved both the layout and the content on the About page, which now spans multiple sub-pages with a design similar to the existing Documentation. Moreover, we have resolved bugs in the GEM Browser and the Map Viewer, and improved documentation-related content. In addition, the process of deploying the software stack has seen some much-wanted attention to improve the robustness, thus paving the way for more regular releases. More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2021.title: Metabolic Atlas 2.2 fixes critical bugs
2021.text: Metabolic Atlas 2.2 is out. In this minor release we focused on resolving several serious bugs that were discovered since the previous release, primarily around the Interaction Partner and Map Viewer tools, and also some smaller bugs that were previously reported. More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2021.title: Metabolic Atlas was presented at the annual GOTBIN workshop
2021.text: Metabolic Atlas was presented an the Gothenburg Bioinformatics Network (GOTBIN) annual workshop.

2021.title: Metabolic Atlas 2.1 revamps Data overlay
2021.text: Metabolic Atlas 2.1 is out. In this minor release we focused on improving the usability of the website, either through feature re-implementation, as was the case for the Data overlay, or through independent fixes. Moreover, several small new features were added, for example the Identifier pages. More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2021.title: Metabolic Atlas was presented in an ELIXIR course
2021.text: Metabolic Atlas was presented in the ELIXIR course Omics Integration and Systems Biology course given by NBIS, as the ELIXIR-SE node, with materials being publicly available on the course homepage and on Zenodo.

2021.title: Metabolic Atlas 2.0
2021.text:
We are excited to announce official release of Metabolic Atlas 2.0 together with the publication of Genome-scale metabolic network reconstruction of model animals as a platform for translational research ðŸŽ‰
Visually, the development efforts have alternated between implementing specific features, for example a highly performant and more lightweight 3D viewer, and a dynamic comparison between models, and implementing incremental improvements to the user experience, for example a faster way to search, random suggestions for the Interaction Partners, and a new home page layout. Moreover, a sleuth of bugs, some introduced by the new technology stack, have been fixed.
Content-wise, this 2.0 release integrates 5 new GEMs next to the updated Human-GEM and Yeast-GEM, bringing the total to 7 integrated models. With this, new IDs for reactions and metabolites have been created for 6 of these models. These new IDs have been updated on the manually created 2D maps, replacing the previous IDs.
More details can be found on GitHub or on Zenodo.

2021.title: Metabolic Atlas was presented in an NBIS course
2021.text: Metabolic Atlas was presented in the Omics Integration and Systems Biology course given by NBIS, with materials available on Zenodo.

2020.title: Metabolic Atlas was presented in a workshop
2020.text: A poster of Metabolic Atlas was presented in the Workshop on Modelling in Biology and Medicine in Gothenburg, Sweden.

2020.title: Metabolic Atlas was presented in an NBIS course
2020.text: Metabolic Atlas was presented in the Omics Integration and Systems Biology course given by NBIS, with materials available on Zenodo.

2020.title: Metabolic Atlas at Elixir All Hands
2020.text: A poster of Metabolic Atlas has been shown at the virtual Elixir All Hands.

2020.title: Metabolic Atlas 1.7 brings Map Viewer improvements
2020.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.7 is out. This release links the genes and metabolites directly to the maps, and improves the Map Viewer links to be more share-friendly. The overall appearance of the website has also been tweaked. More details can be found on GitHub.

2020.title: Metabolic Atlas 1.6
2020.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.6 is out, in connection with the publication of the research article An atlas of human metabolism, and the press release at Chalmers University. This release contains many user interface improvements, documentation updates and correction of typos. More details can be found on GitHub.

links.intro: Update: For more information on the publication see the

2020.title: Metabolic Atlas 1.5 updates both integrated models
2020.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.5 is out. This release updates the layout of the Home, Explore, and Interaction Partner pages. A News section has also been added on the About page. Other features include suggestions on the Search page, a contact button in the GEM Browser, and a progress bar at the top indicating page loading status. The Human-GEM has also been updated to 1.3, and the Yeast-GEM to 8.3.4. More details can be found on GitHub.

2019.title: Metabolic Atlas was presented in an NBIS course
2019.text: Metabolic Atlas was presented in the Omics Integration and Systems Biology course given by NBIS.

2019.title: Metabolic Atlas 1.4 enables gene expression comparison
2019.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.4 is out. The main feature of this release is the Data overlay panel on the Map Viewer, currently enabling data upload and comparison for gene expression. Other small tweaks on the Map Viewer are: the full screen mode, hiding genes or subsystem highlights, some button layout changes. The RNA legend was refactored but maintains the same functionality. The GEM Browser tiles can be randomized by clicking a button. More details can be found on GitHub.

2019.title: Metabolic Atlas 1.3
2019.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.3 loads much faster. Across the website enzyme has been renamed to gene, and the Global search gives results in order, downloadable in TSV format. Among the minor tweaks are: notice on 404 page, Interaction partners layout and API layout. More details can be found on GitHub.

2019.title: Metabolic Atlas is upgraded to 1.2 with Human-GEM updated to 1.1
2019.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.2 adds more interaction on the 3D Map Viewer, and improves the GEM Comparison tables. It also contains several bug fixes. More details can be found in on GitHub. Moreover, Human-GEM was updated to 1.1.

2019.title: Metabolic Atlas is upgraded to 1.1
2019.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.1 has minor UI improvements, mainly around documentation, resources, Interaction Partners and Map Viewer, alongside deployment improvements with a focus on reducing downtime. More details can be found on GitHub.

2019.title: Metabolic Atlas is publicly available as 1.0
2019.text: Metabolic Atlas 1.0 is publicly available. We have finalized two main tools, the GEM Browser (including Interaction Partners) and Map Viewer. Additionally, Metabolic Atlas is hosting GEMs in a repository. More details can be found in on GitHub.
Human-GEM is integrated, with complete compartment maps, and a significant number of the subsystem maps.

2018.text: New manually curated maps for Human-GEM are being created, and the MapViewer is faster when browsing these maps.
Draft models of Human-GEM and Yeast-GEM have been integrated on the 23rd and 28th respectively.
Development on Metabolic Atlas is coordinated by Mihail Anton from NBIS in close collaboration with SysBio, headed by Prof. Nielsen.

2017.text: The project is coordinated by Prof. Nielsen.

2016.text: The framework behind Metabolic Atlas is coordinated by Lena Hansson from NBIS in close collaboration with SysBio, under the direction of Prof. Nielsen.
Work on a new Atlas began in the GitHub repository, directed by Prof. Nielsen.

2015.text: A first Atlas focusing on human metabolism is made publicly available at metabolicatlas.org, with the associated publication Human metabolic atlas: an online resource for human metabolism.
